s.text: Instead of waiting for judgment day, watch-salesman Eyman is hastening it with "Son of 695."
The second part of I-695 achieved disintermediation: It prevents any state or local jurisdiction from raising taxes or fees without a vote of the people.

This tax-cutting initiative, which he is readying for the November 2000 election, will cap annual property-tax appraisals at 2 percent and exempt vehicles from the property tax (on the long shot that the government might start taxing cars as property).
So, if the city of Seattle wants to so much as boost late fees on library books, it has to ask the voters.
The biggest applause line on election night came when Eyman screamed, "From now on, the politicians are going to have to ask your permission to take your money."
Or will they stay the course and ask government to do more with less?
